meeting_annotations.speaker: Xiao Su @ UIUC
meeting_annotations.others_expression: Greeshma is thoughtful, preparing to speak.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker is cut off before finishing his thought.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Greeshma Gadikota
meeting_annotations.transcript: If you want to form carbonates, you really want to form calcium carbonate or magnesium carbonate because they're the least soluble and they'll drop out of your solution pretty quickly. If you're trying to form sodium carbonate, bicarbonate, potassium, group one carbonates, they still tend to stick around. In which case you need to do an anti-solvent crystallization approach where you'd want to use ethanol to precipitate out a more soluble salt. So there are ways to work around it. The challenge really is the low solubility of CO2 in water in general. So there are ways to accelerate that then that can, I think that would really address the challenge related to ocean capture too.
meeting_annotations.others_expression: Xiao Su is listening intently and nodding. Katherine is engaged.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker uses hand gestures to emphasize her points.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Katherine Hornbostel
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I've actually been on a team that's playing with the idea of trying to drive calcium carbonate precipitation from ocean water when you'd remove CO2. If you do it enough, if you pull enough CO2, you can drive that reaction and actually make kind of this sand-like material. So, yeah, like you said, it makes a lot of sense if you're trying to remove more CO2, you can actually drive that precipitation reaction.
meeting_annotations.others_expression: Greeshma and Xiao Su are listening and nodding.
meeting_annotations.other: She builds on the previous speaker's point with a real-world example.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Xiao Su @ UIUC
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, because I think I saw a paper from Argonne where they were capturing carbonate and then shifting that reaction and then sinking more CO2.
meeting_annotations.other: He uses hand gestures to illustrate the chemical process he's describing.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Katherine Hornbostel
meeting_annotations.others_expression: Xiao Su is pausing his speech.
meeting_annotations.other: This is a brief backchannel to show agreement.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Xiao Su @ UIUC
meeting_annotations.transcript: But I'm not sure if it's like, if folks think it's feasible or whatever, but.
meeting_annotations.other: A long, thoughtful pause follows this statement.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Chris Jones - Georgia Tech
meeting_annotations.transcript: I wonder if it's worthwhile for us as we're getting to the end of our session to maybe look at the PowerPoint summary of what we've talked about, look at that together and see if it captures most of the major things that we've we've done. Does anybody want to share that?
meeting_annotations.others_expression: The other participants are listening attentively.
meeting_annotations.other: He takes on a facilitator role to transition the meeting to its next phase.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Chris Jones - Georgia Tech
meeting_annotations.transcript: Or maybe I can share it. I can make sure that I've got it here. I have so many darn windows open, see if I can find it.

meeting_annotations.transcript: I do have it. I can share it. I don't know, do I have the permission to share?
